name: Northern Lapwing
description: It has contrasting black-and-white plumage, a back with a green metallic sheen, broad rounded wings, and a long crest on its head.
spread_note: Almost all of Europe, northwestern Africa
proportions: Length 26–31 cm; wingspan 67–72 cm; weight 140–320 g
reproduction: Females lay 3–4 speckled eggs, incubating them for 26–28 days.
attractions: Outside the breeding season, it forms sizable flocks. It is very hardy, with courtship often beginning in February. The male performs a dramatic display, climbing steeply then diving sharply toward the ground, pulling up just above the surface. During this, it emits a loud, wailing call, earning it the folk name 'kníhora' (wailing bird). The nest is a shallow scrape in the soil. It breeds across most of Europe; some populations migrate to southern Europe and northwestern Africa, while others are resident.
breeding: Records of breeding are unfortunately incomplete—lapwings are documented in 1939 and 1940, then not again until recent times, when five birds arrived from Ohrada Zoo in 2005.
